question: 係わる
userExplanation: verbs ending on <ja>わる</ja> are usually intransitive
sourceMnemonic:
You know that the kanji means <kanji>connection</kanji>. This is a verb, so one meaning is <vocabulary>to be connected</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be related</vocabulary>. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.

Does this all sound familiar? In fact, this is another way to write <ja>関わる</ja>, which you already learned! The two have exactly the same meaning, but this version is a bit less common.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It's exactly the same as the reading for <ja>関わる</ja>, so here's a reminder of that mnemonic to help you:

Remember the "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (<ja>かか</ja>) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw"... You don't want <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> with them.
